Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cross-Scale Assessment of Spatiotemporal Patterns and Drivers of Fire Effects in Mixed-Severity Fire Regime Forests of the Northern Rockies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project is about the influence of climatic variability and topographic gradients on the spatial and temporal variation of landscape patterns of fire severity from the 1700s to the present. Both fire frequency and the annual area burned are strongly related to regional climate and have exhibited increasing trends over recent decades in relation to global warming. However, the ecological effects of increased fire activity are not clearly understood. As a measure of tree mortality, fire severity directly describes one of the major ecological impacts of wildfires. But how sensitive fire severity is to climatic factors or other controls (i.e. topographic factors, vegetation characteristics) is poorly understood. Because fire severity in many forest ecosystems varies over both space and time, long time series of fire severity that quantify spatial patterns of heterogeneity are necessary, both to capture the full range of fire effects and to identify the key drivers of this variation. This is especially true for forests characterized by mixed-severity fire regimes where fire severity is known to be highly variable. This research will adopt a spatially explicit nested research design combining intensive tree-ring sampling, extensive analyses of historical high resolution aerial photography and satellite-based change detection methods to address three primary research goals: 1) to quantify the spatiotemporal variability of fire severity within multiple watersheds from about 1700-present; 2) to evaluate the strength of climatic and topographic controls on landscape patterns of fire severity; and 3) to compare fire severity patterns between historical and contemporary wildfires to assess the role of climate change on fire regime shifts between the two periods. These questions will be examined for Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) dominated forests and mixed-conifer western larch (Larix occidentalis) dominated forests, two of the dominant low-middle elevation forests in the northern Rocky Mountains known to exhibit mixed-severity fire regimes.

Information about how spatiotemporal patterns of fire severity have varied over time and which factors have driven this variability is an important framework for scientists, land managers and others interested in past and future ecological effects of wildfires. The detailed understanding of climate-fire severity relationships provided by this research is a novel and necessary foundation for accurate modeling of future fire severity and land management planning in response to currently shifting climatic conditions. Results from this research will be published in various publications and presented to academic and management audiences. Findings will also be broadly disseminated through ongoing partnerships with National Park Service (NPS) managers, U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Forest Service managers and researchers, and investigators at other several universities involved in related research. The project involves the training of undergraduate and graduate students, and as a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award will provide needed support to a promising doctoral student at a critical stage of career development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mixed-severity fire regimes (MSFRs) are characterized by temporally and spatially variable patterns of fire-caused tree mortality. MSFRs are widespread in western North America, but their ecological dynamics, spatio-temporal variability, and resilience to climate change or alternative management strategies are poorly understood. In this research, we address some of the key methodological limitations to reconstructing spatio-temporal fire severity patterns by combining annually-resolved, multi-century dendroecological records and spatially-explicit patterns of forest structure derived using photogrammetric techniques. Specifically, we use photogrammetric analysis of aerial photographs from the 1930-50s to map historical forest structures and patch boundaries across seven watersheds in two ecoregions within the northern U.S. Rockies paired with a spatially-distributed network of dendroecological sample sites across each watershed. Using this unique multi-proxy dataset, we (1) develop a cross-scale fire severity reconstruction method that combines both data types, (2) evaluate fire-mediated ecological dynamics and resilience mechanisms in a comparative framework between each ecoregion, (3) develop a forest structure-based fire severity model that allows spatially-explicit fire severity reconstructions over large areas, and (4) use this model to evaluate the spatial patterns and biophysical drivers of fire severity variation across five watersheds.

 

We demonstrate that uncertainty in dendroecological fire history reconstructions is highest for MSFRs compared to low- or high-severity fire regimes, but that many of these challenges can be met using the combined photogrammetric and dendroecological datasets and a careful analytical approach. We present a method that allows inferences about fire frequency and severity from dendroecological plots (10-2 ha) to be scaled to forest patches (100-104 ha) mapped from aerial photos. We show that with this approach, both the spatial and temporal characteristics of historical fire severity can be reconstructed over a broad range of spatial (patches, watersheds, landscapes) and temporal scales (e.g. up to 350 years).

 

Our reconstructions reveal that high-severity fire was widespread across the dry and moist mixed-conifer forests of our study region, affecting over 80% of our dendroecological sites and suggesting a notable resilience to high-severity fire across a range of spatial scales (100 - 103 ha). In contrast to expectations based on previous research, rather than create a landscape-scale positive feedback where high-severity fire begets more high-severity fire, most patches affected by high-severity fire subsequently experienced low-moderate severity fires within less than 100 years. The result of this mixed-severity fire regime was a patchwork of young and intermediate-aged forests (< 200 years old) characterized by simple, even-aged and multi-cohort age structures. Based on these observations, we hypothesize that the intermediate median fire frequencies (30-50 years) of our study watersheds resulted in the occurrence of fires during the early stages of successional development that are characterized by low ecosystem flammability. The high spatial heterogeneity and lower fuel abundance of this early successional stage appears to have down-regulated fire behavior and facilitated escape from the high-severity feedback loop documented in other ecosystems. We suggest that this previously undocumented dynamic conferred substantial resilience to high-severity fire in historical MSFRs and we suggest that this mechanism may be increasingly important under climate-driven increases in fire frequency and severity.

 

Our structure-based fire severity model revealed complex, nonlinear relationships between photogrammetrically-derived forest structures and patch-level fire severity history that have not been previously documented. Such strong nonlinearities highlight the critical need for rigorous, data-driven evaluation of structure-based interpretations of fire history. Our analysis also demonstrates the importance of empirical evaluation of the distinct spatial and temporal constraints inherent to each method when combining multiple historical data types to achieve cross-scale, spatio-temporal inferences. Once these constraints were accounted for, our model showed similar or improved performance compared to other historical reconstructions and even modern remotely sensed assessments of fire severity.

 

By applying the model to patches in five photogrametrically-mapped watersheds, we demonstrate that patches with different fire severity histories were highly intermixed within watersheds, suggesting non equilibrium dynamics at the patch-scale. We also document significant biogeographic variation in the fire regime characteristics of individual watersheds along a latitudinal gradient. We show that biogeographic differences in the percent of watershed area and median patch size of each fire severity class were most strongly driven by the median watershed fire frequency and vapor pressure deficit.

 

This research involved 14 undergraduates in field (4 students) and laboratory (9 students) research and one international graduate student from Italy. One undergraduate honors thesis was based on data collected and analyzed by one of these students. The project also involved federal agency researchers and fire managers in the data interpretation, writing and extension activities. Our results have been featured in discussions of mixed-severity fire ecology and management implications in two collaborative groups based in Montana and Oregon. Data and results from this project have been presented at over half a dozen scientific meetings, two papers have been published, two will be submitted this month and two more are in preparation.
